SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.
Your full name: Miss Catherine Elizabeth Coalican
Present Address: 1925 McFutype St., Regina
Pioneer Address: Wainwright
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1905

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? about three or four
   How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? About once a week

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Weekly, on Sundays

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Sometimes by invitation
   What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Mostly in the afternoon but sometimes for the day
   What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes, very often

   How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Some such expression

   If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Coffee or tea or light lunch

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Very often the whole family

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? I don't remember many of these

   Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.
   Mostly dances in the houses - the music, month after month or concertina

   Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

   Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Not to my knowledge
PIONEER INTERVIEW FORM

1. In the first few years, how many homes were there enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's houses?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Did you ever have a house party or dinner party?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays, or other days? How often?

4. Have you often visited other homes, or was visiting done without an invitation? Sometimes by invitation.

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon?

5. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "make potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

6. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there any parties, whilst drives or dances in houses described?

Were those more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?
   What material was it made of? How large was it?
   Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?
   Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?
   To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?
    How were babies and small children provided for?
    How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Whist
    Was there card playing for a prize? Not in the early days
    What dances were popular? Square dances

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. Accepted by all
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community games, box socials, and other activities (include also the school Christmas tree, town dances, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Describe.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall if there was no school house nearby)? Describe.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 9), and how did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home or far community gatherings? Explain.

Accepted by all
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?  
   No ceremony to my knowledge

13. Was the chivaree known in your community?  
   Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.  
   No knowledge

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?  
   Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes –  
   Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.  
   I cannot tell you this. My brother Mr. B. Coolican assisted in the formation. He was President for several years until his death in 1925.  
   Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? Most of them.  
   How many women belonged? None  
   How often did it meet? 3  
   What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? No  
   When was it organized?  
   Approximately how many women belonged to it?  
   Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
